introduction:

Disclaimer, I'm not advocating for developers at Inbound to not meet up and have a good time and trade war stories and walk away with some awesome ideas. Let's get someone to share that information in slack or a blog.  I'm advocating for a more inclusive developer day if HubSpot isn't going to run it. If you don't care to hear my opinion or the reason why, don't read below. If you are interested in my take, please read on. These are just my thoughts and not "beliefs" so they can be changed easily.

SO.. I've sat on this for 24 hours and I've done some thinking on developer day as a whole and what I've seen in the past 6 years. This is going to be a wall of text. I apologize and will give you the TLDR up front. A non HubSpot sponsored developer day should be virtual. The time and effort it takes to set up what is wanted to do, then share it with the community that aren't there is WAY TOO HIGH. There is a lot involved with this. I appreciate everyone's effort here but we can have a much more successful developer day if we do this virtually.
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1K6z2VKq1jSJ6LJjC5w68mrU90A1AocpzZG9IHpFxWDI/edit?usp=sharing>
Here is the google doc that has the rest of the details in it. Everyone has "comment" access to this if you wish to comment or discuss in here
I have no objections to the sentiment of that doc.  I dont understand why both cannot be done
this could be the genesis of a more regular thing
and i do like to be as inclusive as possible, but i also like to meet people IRL.  that connection is meaningful
One of my favorite things about dev day last year was getting together at the bar and talking to all the other devs while we played games
and that is easy to make happen and requires little to no effort to arrange
and i do believe the spirit of this is to not abuse the wonderful human resources we have at HubSpot.
I admit, i am freaking new to this community, but the way people are engaging with this seems like something that could lead to an even more meaningful, robust community.

this slack group is easily the most engaged group that is composed of non employees.  It has a great energy and i am constantly in awe.  Having the opportunity to meet in person with even just a handful will be great.  Add to that having speakers from the community who are trail blazers just makes it so much more worth doing this.  This is not in any way exclusive to people.  I may be speaking out of turn, but everything will be made available somehow online.  And we can use this experiment to do something more frequent/ *sustainable*.  I have not reviewed the above so apologies for rambling :slightly_smiling_face:
i needed about ten more minutes of thought to make that last <p> clearer
(for posterity's sake, i will add the above to that doc)
i am surprised the typically verbose <@U7SL518D6> has not voiced his opinion.  wouldnt mind hearing thoughts from others as well
looks like he's offline lol
weird
:slightly_smiling_face:
I know, wth would a dev have to do on a friday afternoon/evening?

friday should be cocktails
haha just catching up guys. had like a 20 minute meeting and came out to needing to read the equivalent of the first chapter of a book

noted with thanks.  i have been doing these late night friday launches for too long
_verbose_
:wink:
granted, <@U25PYL3Q8> wrote a novel, too. let's see if jon's will make the limit

I've been thinking about it since yesterday and I have a lot of feelings, I love what Jon has put out so far and I commend his effort. I wanted to say my words and see if I could influence a more social get together at inbound and work to have a more inclusive get together virtually
I quit by lead dev role at square 2 and am now on my own
I'm not sure I can make inbound this year
I'm not sure I can make developer day - I have legit questions if I can pay my bills. I mean, I hope I can --

I still need to read <@U25PYL3Q8> doc, but wanted to voice my thoughts on what’s voiced in the slack before i dig into that.

The physical developer day idea is to enable a couple things - Those of us that can get our companies to ship us out there, if we’re just there to network with the marketers that’s not usually worth our ticket and travel costs. When there is a physical event that we may benefit from regarding education and whatnot. we do have a good reason to be there, and are networking with people who are arguably more valuable for us to network with long term.

I think you were eluding to the fact that due to the delay in content being made available online from last years event, AND the fact that the meetup last year felt kind of like a “cool kids club”.

With the community run ideas I was thinking - we can scrap some of the things that makes it hard for HubSpot to run this kind of stuff.

Most of us in the community don’t care about the recordings of the content being perfect before it goes online. We’re also happy to do things more informally. We’re a big group of web developers attending an event for web developers, if we can’t collectively make it so other web developers who couldn’t physically make it don’t feel included, and don’t get a high quality experience, I feel - what are we doing with our careers? lol If anyone can put something on the web it should be us.

So the ideas were to strip out the niceties that HubSpot Corporate would feel they need because they have to meet expectations, and really focus on what the developers want. Content from people doing cool things in the community - news from HubSpot related to what we do, and community building.
sorry I wrote the mile long message Nick tried not to. I’ll shut up now and read his doc. :slightly_smiling_face:
delay in content wasn't a topic I touch on. I'd consider all of that an issue now that I think about it.
I'm headed out with my wife for my birthday dinner

ahh awesome!
I do think you are on to something Jon --
and I think it is atainable but I thnk we can scale it back some and think about it somewhat differently

okay just read through the whole doc.

I totally empathize with all of it and I’m glad you voiced your feedback, absolutely we need to put emphasis on the online side of things

whether we use inbound time meet up to run through some of our presentations and work out some other logistics and think about other topics we can all present on to really get the quality of content we would want to have
I got squeemish when I got to the second part of the doc when we started talking about cost and sponsors. All of that work really would take away from what we do best -- develop/teach/mentor
Thanks for getting this started, and regardless if any of my input is taken, I'm still behind you in what you have done and will do whatever I can to support any effort <@U7SL518D6>
wait.  mine was the 9th!
you will get it done!
So I’ll keep noodling here

I have some ideas on how to do this without needing to go as big as the current main doc is going, while providing a great experience for those that DO and DONT physically come to HubSpot events like inbound
i outsourced the taking care of sponsors to someone who is good at that.  hopefully, that helps. Someone who specializes in that.
and the idea of sponsors was also to take weight off of HubSpot generally
my ideal is that this is primarily led, organized and funded by non HubSpot sources
btw, this is a great conversation :slightly_smiling_face:
also, happy father's day
not to you, jon

it is a great conversation, and yes so to Nick’s point, the reason I started up the move to try to do a community thing is because we don’t want to over extend the HS employees -and because it doesn’t make sense for HubSpot to exclusively foot the bill. That’s why there are only 2 mentions of liason for HubSpot type people in the doc - just people
maybe next year lol

So all of this conversation is great I’m going to noodle over it tonight and tomorrow and post some ideas for ways we can actually simplify this reduce the costs way more - provide a great experience for both people physically there and online - during and after the event

Also to all involved in the community and whatnot - no ideas are set in stone - anything can be changed, my initial doc was to get the conversations started and help to coordinate things. Fortunately we have some time before Inbound here.

I have some ideas in my noggin atm I’m going to flesh out and get back to everyone with
Happy Birthday Buddy, didnt know it was today, enjoy the day!

<@UD53A9UUR> if you talk with Sam Carmer - let them know some specific things the sponsorships may be for may change but having atleast financial sponsors will still be beneficial - I realize to sell it to a company they need to know what they get out of it - so we’ll try to figure out the format of all this quickly.
Don't worry about that. One of the companies she is selling this to specializes in tradeshows. So it makes sense for them
